results.title: Trapper Murphy
results.creator_credit: Ronald Mason and Academy Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Describes the menace to sheep of dingoes and foxes in the Bogong High Plains in Victoria and shows something of the way in which they are being exterminated. Includes a shot of dingoes actually killing sheep at night.

Please be advised: this film includes scenes of animals being hunted and destroyed which may be distressing to viewers.

results.title: Australia's anti-war movement: 1965-1972
results.brief_description: The initially small minority protesting against Australian involvement in the Vietnam War flourished into a massive mobilisation against the war that not only ended Australian participation in the war, but also radicalised and irreversibly changed Australian society. In this video three participants in the anti-war movement discuss their involvement. Irene Miller was an original member of the Save Our Sons Movement, one of the earliest of the anti-war organisations. Michael Hamel-Green was a draft resister and he gives a fascinating account of the “underground” movement which worked to protect draft resisters from prison by installing them in “safe houses”. Jean McLean discusses the history of the anti-war movement and the lead up to the first anti-war Moratorium in 1970, the largest protest in Australia’s history.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family ski trip to Falls Creek. We see the interior and exterior of the Winterhaven Ski Lodge and children being towed along by a ski tow. There are closeups and wide shots of skiers as they navigate their way around what appears to be a beginner’s ski run.

The film shows a children’s group ski lesson, a poma and T-bar lift, children skiing towards the camera and people being towed up the slope by the Village T-Bar ski tow. The children learn to ‘hop’ and the signal for ‘follow me’.

We see an adult couple preparing to ski with what appears to be a 1950s/1960s Volkswagen Beetle and pick-up truck parked in the background.

There are some lovely snow-covered landscapes of Falls Creek with people skiing in the sunshine against the backdrop of a bright blue sky.

A Snow Cat (vehicle) drives through the snow, passing ski lodges on the way.

A teenage boy runs beside a creek at the foot of a snow-covered embankment. We see a fishing expedition to the same creek, where fishing rods are prepared with bait and tackle, and two men and a boy cast their rods into the creek.

On the deck of Winterhaven Lodge, a group of people wearing shorts, swimwear and sunglasses lie on sun lounges enjoying the winter sun with the snow-covered embankment behind them. A woman wearing a bikini lies on a sun lounge beside her male companion who smokes and reads a book. Both are sporting 1960s sunglasses in the winter sun. We see a view from the deck of the ski lodge, showing snow-covered hills and surrounding ski lodges below.

The final section of the film follows a lone skier as he traverses his way down an empty slope.

This film shows good examples of fashion, ski wear, swimwear and sunglasses worn in the 60s. Ski Lodge architecture, vehicles and Falls Creek landscapes in this film are also a great reflection of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Film title: “Falls Creek 1962”
00:03:20:00 Father and son in tandem being pulled together on a tow rope
00:09:37:00 Ski School lesson with children
00:09:54:00 Man and woman preparing to ski with Volkswagen Beetle and c1950s pick-up truck parked in the background. Good fashion and vehicle example here
00:11:06:00 Wide shot of four skiers skiing down a slope
00:19:28:00 High shot taken from ski lodge of boy with skis with a snow-covered sunbed in the background
00:19:35:00 Vintage Snow Cat (vehicle) travels through the snow with dogs following, passing ski lodges along the way
00:22:06:00 Skiers and the landscape of Falls Creek
00:22:23:00 Snow and creek vista
00:22:45:00 Boy playing beside creek in the snow
00:23:54:00 Creek snow fishing expedition
00:25:48:00 People lounging in sun beds at the ski lodge, dressed in shorts, swimwear and sunglasses
00:26:02:00 View from the deck of the ski lodge showing snow-covered hills and lodges below
00:26:10:00 Woman lying on sun lounge wearing a bikini and eating an orange
00:26:21:00 Man lying on sun lounge smoking and reading a book
00:26:51:00 View of snow-covered hills and lodges
00:27:28:00 A lone skier skis down an empty slope

results.title: Feathers
results.brief_description: A riotous social comedy based on a short story by acclaimed American writer, Raymond Carver. Jack and Bert, factory workers, share a strange and magical evening with their respective wives at Bert’s rural retreat. Gradually the city couple are seduced into sharing the simple pleasures and eccentricities of their friends. Rated: PG

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The notes accompanying this film indicate that the footage is taken while on holiday in Queensland in 1955.

This film opens with rural landscape scenes of lush vegetation with mountains in the background. We see pine trees, fence posts and wire as well as a small out-house type construction made of wood with a corrugated iron roof. It could be an outdoor toilet.

There is footage of various varieties of tropical fish including butterfly fish, and varieties of coral including brain coral and large shells. These scenes appear to be shot through glass, so they could be at an Aquarium or on a glass-bottomed boat.

We see scenes of a whale watching expedition, with the top of a whale just visible above the water. There is also some water ski action which seems to be taking place on a dam or weir.

Originally made using 16mm film.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Most of this film shows a family enjoying the Falls Creek snowfields circa 1966/1967. There are also scenes of children playing in a Mirror or possibly a Sabot sailing boat dry-docked in a suburban back yard.

There are sequences of slalom ski events, chair lift and poma lift rides, and family leisure time spent inside the ski lodge.

We see ski races with slalom pole banners with “Molony Ski Shop” signage, and “Start” and “Finish” banners and flags with “Henke Schuhe” signage. A ski instructor wearing a red Parka teaching parallel turns. The old ski jump is visible down the valley.

A group of family and friends go down the Valley of the Moon ski run. A child navigates the tricky bits, then skis along the narrow raceline to the village. We see currawongs in the trees, a village, and return on the chairlift.

The filmmaker experiments with some in-camera slow-motion techniques, and amongst the crowd of onlookers and prize givers, we see people using what could be a Standard 8 camera or a 16mm Bolex camera, as well as 35mm SLR cameras.

There are some beautiful ski scenes filmed against blue skies amongst eucalypts and beside streams. A high shot provides an excellent view of the slalom course with flags and banners. We see a lovely panorama of green hills patched with snow in the background and views of the ski feild from the Snowhaven deck.

The film shows some great scenes of a man in charge of a “Snow mobile” as he starts it up and tows four skiers behind him. They traverse the beautiful snow-covered countryside in formation, across towards Mt McKay. Looking down over Sun Valley and a very long tow queue.

In a suburban backyard seemingly far from the snow fields, the film shows two children playing in a dry-docked Fireball sailing boat. We see the young boy strapped into the boat’s flying trapeze harness as he swings from the edge of the boat. The children play with a toy ambulance and ride down the street (Cleeve Court) on their bicycles. Along the street, we see vintage cars and suburban houses.

This film has good examples of ski fashion, winter snow fashion, snow vehicles, ski techniques, recreation, and leisure activities particular to the era.

The footage of the Falls Creek landscape is a good historical reflection of the topography of Falls Creek during the 60s. There are also good examples of a suburban street scape, children’s toys and sailing boats used for recreation.

This film was originally made on 16mm.

Selected highlights list:
00: 05:22:00 High shot of finish line, flags and skiers
00:13:47:00 Skiing alongside a stream
00:14:00:00 Skiers in single file navigate a narrow path
00:16:37:00 Women and children ski downhill towards the ski village
00:20:16:00 A young boy boards the poma tow
00:20:53:00 Children playing in Fireball sailing boat
00:23:05:00 Snow Cruiser driver starts the engine
00:23:57:00 Skiers in formation behind Snow Cruiser
00:25:20:00 Skiers single file behind Snow Cruiser

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
This film opens with shots of snow-capped mountains, Mt Spion Kopje and Mt Bogong, as a backdrop to the surrounding green bushland. Cutting a swathe through the bush is a dirt track lined with electricity transmission towers.

On the mountain, we see children and adults learning to use their skis. There are lots of falls and numerous attempts to stand up again. There is some sled action on a type of sled typical to the era, and a big home-made metal sled with steering. Everyone herringbones back up the slope. Using the rope tow and ducking under the return rope .

We see skiers ski in front of a building with the signage “Ski School”.

There are lovely individual scenes of a man and a woman skiing past the camera dressed in the ski fashion of the day. A group of people practise their ski moves in front of the “Falls Creek Comfort Station”.

Colourfully dressed children navigate the ski slopes, and an elderly man dressed in a coat and feathered trilby-style hat tries his hand at skiing.

We see a lovely scene of the family as they take a break from skiing to have a picnic sitting in the snow. They have their thermos flask, sandwiches, and cordial.

The film shows people being towed uphill and past a building with “ski lodge” signage.

There are various scenes of skiers congregating together on the slopes and wide shots of them skiing in across and down the slopes.

The final part of the film shows what could be accommodation Bogong Village. The village was originally constructed by the Victorian State Electricity Utility Commissions (SEC) from the 1930s and 1950s to house workers on the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme.

We see historic vehicles c1950/ 1960 with Victorian registration plates beginning with HEW: 4, parked in the street at the front of the houses. There are images of people as they walk down the street with the mountains in the background.

This film shows good examples of fashion, ski wear, and ski techniques in the 60s. Ski Lodge architecture, Bogong Village architecture, vehicles and Falls Creek and Bogong Village landscapes are also a great historic reflection of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film

Selected highlights list:
00:02:00:00 Title “Falls Creek 1960”
00:00:32:00 Snow-capped mountain with tree covered slopes in the foreground
00:01:26:00 A young boy struggles to get to his feet after a fall
00:01:35:00 A young boy stands with his skis over his shoulder in the snow
00:02:09:00 A young boy plays in the snow beside his stocks. A good example of children’s fashion
00:03:38:00 A young boy going down the hill on a sled
00:04:02:00 A young boy going down the hill on a sled in front of the ski school building
00:04:25:00 A woman skis passed the ski school building
00:05:23:00 Close up of above
00:06:41:00 A man skis down the slope. A good example of ski fashion
00:11:01:00 Ski school participants learn to parallel ski
00:11:39:00 Film title “Falls Creek 1961”
00:11:44:00 A group of skiers stand around a ski run with a hut or lodge on the mountain as a backdrop
00:11:54:00 Ski lodges against a blue sky and snow-covered landscape
00:12:55:00 Two stylishly dressed young boys wearing goggles and beanies walk past the camera on their skis
00:13:06:00 “private lessons” sign stands in front a building with skiers moving past
00:13:20: 00 A small girl joyfully skis past the camera
00:13:51:00 Two boys ski down the hill from a lodge
00:14:16:00 A young boy dressed in in red skis down the hill past the camera
00:14: 30:00 An elderly man dressed in his trilby-style hat is trying to ski
00:15:36:00 A family picnic in the snow
00:16:34:00 Two boys hitch a ride on the ski tow
00:17:36:00 A man is towed past the ski school lodge
00:18:22:00 A man in a cap and sunglasses preparing to ski
00:23:45:00 Blue skies and a congregation of skiers
00:24:06:00 Houses and street scene of what could be Bogong Village
00:24:31:00 Houses and street scene of what could be Bogong Village with snow-capped mountain in the background
results.description:
This film opens with shots of snow-capped mountains, Mt Spion Kopje and Mt Bogong, as a backdrop to the surrounding green bushland. Cutting a swathe through the bush is a dirt track lined with electricity transmission towers.

On the mountain, we see children and adults learning to use their skis. There are lots of falls and numerous attempts to stand up again. There is some sled action on a type of sled typical to the era, and a big home-made metal sled with steering. Everyone herringbones back up the slope. Using the rope tow and ducking under the return rope .

We see skiers ski in front of a building with the signage “Ski School”.

There are lovely individual scenes of a man and a woman skiing past the camera dressed in the ski fashion of the day. A group of people practise their ski moves in front of the “Falls Creek Comfort Station”.

Colourfully dressed children navigate the ski slopes, and an elderly man dressed in a coat and feathered trilby-style hat tries his hand at skiing.

We see a lovely scene of the family as they take a break from skiing to have a picnic sitting in the snow. They have their thermos flask, sandwiches, and cordial.

The film shows people being towed uphill and past a building with “ski lodge” signage.

There are various scenes of skiers congregating together on the slopes and wide shots of them skiing in across and down the slopes.

The final part of the film shows what could be accommodation Bogong Village. The village was originally constructed by the Victorian State Electricity Utility Commissions (SEC) from the 1930s and 1950s to house workers on the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme.

We see historic vehicles c1950/ 1960 with Victorian registration plates beginning with HEW: 4, parked in the street at the front of the houses. There are images of people as they walk down the street with the mountains in the background.

This film shows good examples of fashion, ski wear, and ski techniques in the 60s. Ski Lodge architecture, Bogong Village architecture, vehicles and Falls Creek and Bogong Village landscapes are also a great historic reflection of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film

Selected highlights list:
00:02:00:00 Title “Falls Creek 1960”
00:00:32:00 Snow-capped mountain with tree covered slopes in the foreground
00:01:26:00 A young boy struggles to get to his feet after a fall
00:01:35:00 A young boy stands with his skis over his shoulder in the snow
00:02:09:00 A young boy plays in the snow beside his stocks. A good example of children’s fashion
00:03:38:00 A young boy going down the hill on a sled
00:04:02:00 A young boy going down the hill on a sled in front of the ski school building
00:04:25:00 A woman skis passed the ski school building
00:05:23:00 Close up of above
00:06:41:00 A man skis down the slope. A good example of ski fashion
00:11:01:00 Ski school participants learn to parallel ski
00:11:39:00 Film title “Falls Creek 1961”
00:11:44:00 A group of skiers stand around a ski run with a hut or lodge on the mountain as a backdrop
00:11:54:00 Ski lodges against a blue sky and snow-covered landscape
00:12:55:00 Two stylishly dressed young boys wearing goggles and beanies walk past the camera on their skis
00:13:06:00 “private lessons” sign stands in front a building with skiers moving past
00:13:20: 00 A small girl joyfully skis past the camera
00:13:51:00 Two boys ski down the hill from a lodge
00:14:16:00 A young boy dressed in in red skis down the hill past the camera
00:14: 30:00 An elderly man dressed in his trilby-style hat is trying to ski
00:15:36:00 A family picnic in the snow
00:16:34:00 Two boys hitch a ride on the ski tow
00:17:36:00 A man is towed past the ski school lodge
00:18:22:00 A man in a cap and sunglasses preparing to ski
00:23:45:00 Blue skies and a congregation of skiers
00:24:06:00 Houses and street scene of what could be Bogong Village
00:24:31:00 Houses and street scene of what could be Bogong Village with snow-capped mountain in the background

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
This film is divided into three parts with the titles: “Falls Creek 1964”; “NEDSA 1965”; “1965 The Year of Parallel Skis”.

This film documents family ski trips to Falls Creek, Victoria.

We see the lodge accommodation, participation in ski competitions, recreational skiing and leisure time spent on the slopes and at the lodge.

The first part of the film shows the family on the deck of Snowhaven Lodge. The children play on the deck, reading the book “Nursery Rhyme and Pastime Book” and what appears to be a selection of Little Golden Books. A young girl knits while sitting beside her siblings and two people prepare to ski beside the lodge wearing snow gear typical to the era.

The second Part of the film is titled “NEDSA 1964”. The acronym stands for North-Eastern District Ski Association which was formed by ski clubs at Falls Creek and Hotham in 1937. Responsible for running inter-club races, we see the children queuing up to participate in a Slalom event. A race official signals the start, and one by one each participant attempts the course. Some successfully complete it – some do not. There is plenty of footage of people falling over. We see the finishing line banner which reads “Kastle Ski” (a brand of skis) and “Finish”.

The film shows timekeepers and other event officials waiting at the end of the run with their stopwatches and megaphone. A podium stands at the base of the finishing line and place getters are presented with their prizes of a silver souvenir teaspoon and trophy.

We see the children aboard a Snow Cat (vehicle), while others are hitched to the back on a tow rope. This section of the film shows a lovely sequence shot from the back of the vehicle showing children and a man being towed up the hill. In particular, the stylish gent wearing a Trilby or Pork Pie style hat and sunglasses cuts a fine figure on the tow rope.

The third part of the film is titled “Falls Creek 1965. The Year of Parallel Skis.” In this section of the film, we can see how the family has progressed in their skiing abilities with ski lessons and participation in Slalom competition. There are some lovely scenes of skiing without the crowds which includes footage of the panorama and landscape of Falls Creek.

This film has excellent examples of ski village infrastructure, ski fashion, winter snow fashion, snow vehicles, ski techniques, recreation, and leisure activities particular to the era. The footage of the snow lodge and landscape is a good historical reflection of the architecture, furniture, and the topography of Falls Creek during the 60s.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Title: Falls Creek 1964
00:00:18:00 Snowhaven Lodge signage on lodge wall
00:00:27:00 Exterior shot of Snowhaven Lodge
00:01:26:00 Children reading and knitting on the deck of the lodge
00:03:23:00 Two people prepare to ski outside the lodge
00:03:57:00 The family have their meal on the deck of the lodge
00:04:31:00 Title: NEDSA 1964
00:06:25:00 A young girl wearing ski goggles exclaims to the camera
00:06:52:00 Finishing line banner “Kastle Ski” and “Finish”
00:06:57:00 Skiers standing together with snow-covered slopes in the background
00:08:19:00 Timekeepers with stop watches and camera stand together with skiers at the end of a run. A good fashion example here
00:08:24:00 Time keeping officials counting down with their stop watches
00:08:37:00 Ski officials stand beside megaphone and use a telephone-looking device
00:09:07:00 Officials in conversation – a good fashion example here
00:09:38:00 Winners’ podiums set up at the Kastle Finish banner
00:13:00:00 Children watch on board a Snowcat as skiers hitch themselves to the back with a tow rope
00:13:05:00 Children and adult male being towed by the Snowcat
00:17:21:00 Title: Falls Creek 1965
00:17:27:00 Title: The Year of Skis
00:19:53:00 Wide shot of people skiing down and uncrowded slope
00:20:14:00 What could possibly be a family ski together down an uncrowded slope
00:22:44:00 Women stand together in a row watching a lone ski demonstration from one of their party
00:23:12:00 Skiers against an empty snow-covered hill and landscape
00:24:05:00 What could possibly be a father and son ski against an empty snow-covered hill and landscape

results.title: Robert Klippel
results.creator_credit: Keith Salvat, Australia Council and Keisal Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Robert Klippel is viewed as one of Australia’s most important artists of the fifties and sixties. His humble beginnings (and obsession) with ship modelmaking was to influence and inform his work throughout his career as an artist. Klippel was a self-taught artist whose interest sprung from the processes he’d developed while model building, a scale which was to continue in his work throughout his career. Klippel had a strong preference for the solid built form of sculpture but found his work naturally becoming more linear in style. His developed language in the fifties and his need for intellectual peers saw him travel to Europe and New York to again resettle in Sydney, Australia where he developed strong artistic allies and his notoriety as an abstract expressionist artist along with Olsen and Passmore. This documentary charts Klippel’s role in a developing cultural nation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Salvat, Australia Council and Keisal Films

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
This film comprises a slice of family life in suburban Melbourne.

The first scene shows children playing in their backyard under a homemade cubby house constructed of bed sheets, cardboard and possibly curtains. They play with long pieces of bamboo cane, running and dancing around the cubby house. We can see what is probably the rear of the house which is a mid-century modern style. The film shows backyard play equipment such as monkey bars and swings, and neighbouring houses appear in the background.

A young child dressed in cute overalls plays with a colourful ball and is joined by their mother and siblings. There is some lovely footage of the child standing on the garden path surrounded by flowers. A butterfly joins in as the toddler stops to pick some flowers.

The film shows some backyard above-ground swimming pool action. Children enjoy themselves duck-diving for coins, wearing diving masks and somersaulting under water. We see a delightful interaction between siblings as they sit in the sunshine and eat biscuits together.

We see a young child standing beside their mother. She is gardening dressed in her full-piece 1960s swimming costume.

Three children play together in a wading or paddling pool, filling it up with water from the nearby garden hose. They take great delight in creating a flood, squirting each other with water, splashing and jettisoning the water into the air. They play piggy-back in the pool, use plastic kickboards and sit in an improvised plastic boat.

The film shows scenes of children swimming laps in an outdoor inbuilt swimming pool which could be at St Catherine’s School, Toorak. We can see some impressive buildings in the background which could be a part of the school or neighbouring houses.

There is a lovely scene of a young boy riding his tricycle along a leafy suburban street, lined with large houses. The street could be Cleeve Court in Toorak.

We see a young girl playing on a swing surrounded by a beautiful garden in full bloom.

The film finishes with a trip to the country for horse riding lessons. We see the horses being saddled up while they stand under a Hills Hoist clothes line, and the children are taken through their rising trot and cantering paces. The horse riding instructors use wooden sign posts and mallets to mark out a course for the young horse riders.

This film shows great examples of fashion, including swimwear, children’s recreational activities including horse riding and swimming, play equipment, toys and architecture typical of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film

Selected Highlights list:
00:00:56:00 Children playing with long pieces of cane with mid-century modern house in background
00:03:36:00 Small boy and a butterfly on a garden path
00:05:29:00 Brother and sister sit by the swimming pool eating biscuits
00:07:43:00 Mother goes for a swim – good example of swimwear
00:08:35:00 Three children play in a wading pool
00:09:56:00 Children swim laps in an outdoor pool, perhaps at St Catherine’s School, Toorak
00:10:26:00 Children dive into an outdoor pool as above
00:10:37:00 Boy on tricycle riding down a street lined with grand houses, perhaps Cleeve Court, Toorak
00:11:25:00 Children play in wading pool with kickboards and improvised boat

They take great delight in creating a flood, squirting each other with water, splashing and jettisoning the water into the air. They play piggy-back in the pool, use plastic kickboards and sit in an improvised plastic boat.

The film shows scenes of children swimming laps in an outdoor inbuilt swimming pool which could be at St Catherine’s School, Toorak. We can see some impressive buildings in the background which could be a part of the school or neighbouring houses.

There is a lovely scene of a young boy riding his tricycle along a leafy suburban street, lined with large houses. The street could be Cleeve Court in Toorak.

We see a young girl playing on a swing surrounded by a beautiful garden in full bloom.

The film finishes with a trip to the country for horse riding lessons. We see the horses being saddled up while they stand under a Hills Hoist clothes line, and the children are taken through their rising trot and cantering paces. The horse riding instructors use wooden sign posts and mallets to mark out a course for the young horse riders.

This film shows great examples of fashion, including swimwear, children’s recreational activities including horse riding and swimming, play equipment, toys and architecture typical of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film

description_for_label:
This film comprises a slice of family life in suburban Melbourne.

The first scene shows children playing in their backyard under a homemade cubby house constructed of bed sheets, cardboard and possibly curtains. They play with long pieces of bamboo cane, running and dancing around the cubby house. We can see what is probably the rear of the house which is a mid-century modern style. The film shows backyard play equipment such as monkey bars and swings, and neighbouring houses appear in the background.

A young child dressed in cute overalls plays with a colourful ball and is joined by their mother and siblings. There is some lovely footage of the child standing on the garden path surrounded by flowers. A butterfly joins in as the toddler stops to pick some flowers.

The film shows some backyard above-ground swimming pool action. Children enjoy themselves duck-diving for coins, wearing diving masks and somersaulting under water. We see a delightful interaction between siblings as they sit in the sunshine and eat biscuits together.

We see a young child standing beside their mother. She is gardening dressed in her full-piece 1960s swimming costume.

Three children play together in a wading or paddling pool, filling it up with water from the nearby garden hose. They take great delight in creating a flood, squirting each other with water, splashing and jettisoning the water into the air. They play piggy-back in the pool, use plastic kickboards and sit in an improvised plastic boat.

The film shows scenes of children swimming laps in an outdoor inbuilt swimming pool which could be at St Catherine’s School, Toorak. We can see some impressive buildings in the background which could be a part of the school or neighbouring houses.

There is a lovely scene of a young boy riding his tricycle along a leafy suburban street, lined with large houses. The street could be Cleeve Court in Toorak.

We see a young girl playing on a swing surrounded by a beautiful garden in full bloom.

The film finishes with a trip to the country for horse riding lessons. We see the horses being saddled up while they stand under a Hills Hoist clothes line, and the children are taken through their rising trot and cantering paces. The horse riding instructors use wooden sign posts and mallets to mark out a course for the young horse riders.

This film shows great examples of fashion, including swimwear, children’s recreational activities including horse riding and swimming, play equipment, toys and architecture typical of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film
